title: linear algebra - Empirical approaches to validate observational bounds on minimum gap between least eigenvalues of $n \times n$ correlation matrix and its submatrices
body: Let $\Sigma$ be an $n \times n$ correlation matrix whose least eigenvalue is denoted by $\lambda$ . $\Sigma_i'$ be an $(n-1) \times (n-1)$ submatrix of $\Sigma$ obtained by eliminating the $i$ -th row and $i$ -th column and whose least eigenvalue is denoted by $\lambda_i'$ . Find an upper bound on the gap $$\Delta := \min_{i \in \{1,\dots,n\}}(\lambda_i' - \lambda)$$ Empirical Observations: Empirically, I am making some observations about $\Delta$ : $\Delta \leq $ the mean of the absolute values of all off-diagonal entries of $\Sigma$ . $\Delta \leq \frac{||C_{j}||}{n-1} \leq \frac{||C_{j}||_1}{n-1}$ for all $j \in \{1\dots,n\}$ , where $C_j$ denotes a column vector of $\Sigma$ including all off-diagonal entries. $\Delta \leq \frac{1}{n-1}$ , for any $n \times n$ correlation matrix, and the maxima is achieved when all the off-diagonal entries are equal to $\frac{-1}{n-1}$ . I am unable to prove them theoretically yet (More details on theoretical results are discussed on this link ). Hence, I am resorting to empirical approaches that can be convincing enough to validate these observations. A trivial approach could be to check the observations on a large population (say 10^6) of randomly generated correlation matrices. However, such a number doesn't seem to be large enough for bigger matrices.
